A rapidly growing city, Austin is also a hub for innovation. Field Constructs Design Competition grew out of our collective desire to create a new opportunity for emerging architects, landscape architects, designers, and artists to realize and share their work with our community. We have forged connections with incredible partners to make this idea a reality; we launched the competition and responses from many corners of the world have inspired us all; we held a jury with some of the leading-edge experts in architecture, design and art, resulting in a selection of 18 visionary projects; and finally, we recently announced four winning proposals that will be constructed at the site in Austin, the Circle Acres Nature Preserve. The winning teams’ installations, and associated programming, will be on view and free to the public from November 14 to 22, 2015. Our fundraising efforts have allowed us to continue to move forward with this ambitious project so far, but we need your help to bring it to full fruition. The funds raised through this campaign will go toward public programming, operational costs of the overall exhibition at the site, and some of the materials for individual installations.We are excited to tell you more about the winning projects, the Circle Acres site, and the larger mission of Field Constructs Design Competition: A buoyant chain of balloons wired with sensors floating above the landscape; a camouflaged canopy lasercut from polished steel; a brightly-colored egg overgrown with grass; and a patterned root system fabricated on a digital lathe are the four 2015 Field Constructs Design Competition (FCDC) winners. These projects marry experimentation with design innovation while uniquely addressing the history and ecology of the competition site, the Circle Acres Nature Preserve in Austin, Texas. 2015 FCDC WINNERS99 White BalloonsINVIVIA Cambridge, Mass., USABlurred BodiesStudio Roland Snooks Melbourne, AustraliaDuck Blind in Plain SiteOP.AL + And-Either-OrBrooklyn, New York, USAHybrootOTA+Austin, Texas, USAThe winners represent a diverse group of architects, landscape architects, and designers focusing on digital fabrication, material innovation, and interactive design. Themes of camouflage; waste cycles in a landfill; dynamic, repetitive, growth in nature; and interactivity unite the four projects — which will all generate, apply, and test innovative thinking with regard to site specificity, environmental impact, and the use of new technological advancements in design.As small-scale installations on view at Circle Acres from November 14–22, the projects also represent the possibility of engaging the public by promoting the value of contemporary design along with the mission of the Circle Acres Nature Preserve. This will be the first time architectural installations will be installed at Circle Acres. It is a remediated brownfield (meaning a former landfill) and the terrain is varied. We will work hard with each of our winning teams to help with logistics of the site. We also anticipate working with Ecology Action of Texas, and the EAST Austin Studio Tour to promote the installations and get visitors to the site.





About FCDC
In November 2014, Field Constructs Design
Competition invited emerging designers, architects, landscape architects, and
artists to participate in a juried competition to design, fabricate, and
install a site-specific intervention at the Circle Acres Nature Preserve in
Austin, Texas. FCDC’s mission is to explore innovative design ideas using
full-scale installation as a medium, while fostering a dialogue between the
participating designers and the broader public. Award recipients will receive a
$5,000 reimbursable budget toward the realization of the projects. 





About Circle Acres Nature Preserve
The Circle Acres Nature
Preserve and Center for Sustainable Futures is located in East Austin. Ecology Action of Texas purchased the 10-acre retired landfill
in 2010 with the goal of transforming the once-hazardous site into a viable
park for the local neighborhood and the city at large. 
FCDC has joined into a
relationship with Ecology Action, the non-profit organization
in charge of the competition site, Circle Acres Nature Preserve. This collaboration
allows for a rich exploration and fostering of ideas related to sustainability,
design, and creative reuse of a former landfill. Ecology Action of Texas was
founded in 1969 with a mission to create a healthier environment through
resource recovery operations, brownfield remediation, and zero-waste
initiatives.
SponsorsEcology Action of Texas, Texas Architect Magazine, Texas Society of Architects, Pentagram, AIA Austin, Austin Foundation for Architecture, Bustler, Archinect, and MFArchitecture

story:
As you may know, I am working with an international nonprofit called Rotaract, the college-level of Rotary International. Raised from a young age to always look to help, I am proud to say that I have been chosen to represent Rotaract at Tulane University on a Lunches for Learning Graduation Trip.

Lunches for Learning provides free meals to Honduran children in Elementary School, to break the cycle of poverty in the region, where nearly 30% of school-aged children drop out to work for food.  Since 2004, the organization has strived to provide as many lunches as possible to schoolchildren, and have invited involved Rotary clubs, and our Rotaract club, to help spread the word of this awesome organization through a visit that will take us to 3 of the schools they work with to attend their graduations and do service in their community!

story:
Teach North Korean Refugees (TNKR) is a non-political and non-religious humanitarian organization that focuses on assisting adults who have escaped North Korea in preparing for their future. 

The primary focus of TNKR is to provide vital English learning opportunities to refugees and encourage them to study, work, and live after their escape from North Korea.  ALL tutors involved in the project are volunteers, and there is no cost for the refugees. TNKR does not accept government funding - it relies on private donations. 

English is one of the largest barriers for a refugee to become successful in a new country. Without the ability to speak English, they have restricted education and career opportunities.

What makes TNKR different and valuable to refugees is that we provide one-on-one tutoring completely based on needs of refugees. It is a learner-led program. The refugee is able to have as many tutors as he/she wants and personally choose his/her tutor based on tutor expertise. Tutoring sessions are customized based on the learning needs of refugees. The refugee is taught the skills and knowledge he/she actually wants to learn.

The Impact

TNKR has been operating since 2013 with only volunteers and minimal donations. We have had over 200 refugees go through our tutoring program.

This program has also attracted the hearts of people all over the world. We have had over 300 volunteers from different backgrounds, ages, and skills, and it's a grassroots project on the ground, managed locally in Seoul.

What We Need

We want to grow TNKR, and we need your support. We currently have 50+ refugees on our waiting list to begin tutoring, and the organization is ready to expand. 

With this money we plan to:

- begin the North Korean Education Fund, so we can provide scholarships and help find internship and career opportunities that matter 

- create Homework Helper support where refugees can come and seek help with their English courses

- put on our 3rd Speech Competition where refugees are able to share their story and win monetary prizes (Our founders have donated $3,000 to put on the first speech contest.)

- get our own space where refugees and tutors can meet (It costs $10 for each tutoring session when they have to individually rent out private spaces) 

Any donation will be beneficial and allow TNKR to expand its reach!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, please help spread the word, by sharing our IndieGoGo page!

story:
>>>>DONATE NOW, TO HELP TEACHERS ENGAGE STUDENTS!!>>>>>>>>>

QUESTILY ADDRESSES TEACHER'S TOP 3 PROBLEMS: 

ENGAGEMENT, PERSONALIZED LEARNING ("Differentiation"), and NO TIME (to develop custom material, or learn new technologies)

QUESTILY magically combines a FREE Collaborative-Learning App with QUESTS (Made-to-Order Lesson Plans for iPads). Our mission is to foster a love of learning in students by making it simple for any teacher to use available technology (initially iPads) to engage students in self-paced, team-based learning, guided by their own teacher.  With practically ZERO Teacher Training (next-day deployment).
Help Us MAKE LEARNING A TEAM SPORT In Classrooms Across America!


APPS Engage Students.  PAPER Puts Students and Teachers on Same Page.

Questily puts technology into the hands of students, to practice a specific skill in small teams of 2 or 3, at their own pace and style.  Made-to-order paper assessments (Challenges) reinforce digital learning and make it simple to deploy Quests in traditional classrooms with no technology training for teachers.

Your Donation Will Bring Quests to Students Across America!

We need $20,000 to start delivering made-to-order Quests, along with the FREE Questily App (available on October 7 for Grades 1-4 Common Core Math). 


Looking for Innovative Educators to Receive FREE QUESTS!

If you are a Teacher and have iPads, can load (paid and free) apps onto your iPads, and have the permission of your administration, we're looking for RECIPIENT SCHOOLS, to benefit from this Indiegogo Campaign!  Please contact John Miniati directly, john@questily.com.  

*************************************************************************** 

PERKS!  Here's what you (and recipient Schools!) Get:

ALL DONORS GET YOUR NAME (OR NAME OF YOUR FAVORITE TEACHER!) ON THE QUESTILY "I HELPED MAKE LEARNING A TEAM SPORT" PAGE.

>>>>>>>>> READY TO DONATE NOW?    CLICK HERE!! >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>




We are teachers and techies passionate about making learning more fun and engaging for students and easier for teachers.  

Quests are unique in their simplicity and collaborative learning methods.  I evaluated over 250 K-12 ed-tech companies over a two-and-a-half year period, as a product innovation consultant to a leading K-12 educational software firm. This experience helped Questily avoid two significant assumptions that limit technology adoption in classrooms: 

  1. Questily doesn't require any technology training.  Put simply, teachers have no time to learn new technologies.  
  2. Questily doesn't require one device per student ("1-to-1").  As a collaborative learning solution, Questily is most effective with one iPad per team of 2 or 3 students.  

Forget "1-1", why not share 10 iPads across four classrooms?  By pooling iPads, it's not hard to cover four classrooms (of 21-30 students) with 7-to-10 iPads.  This leverages schools' iPad and app investment (neither is included in our solution). Moreover, the Questily App (which IS FREE), makes setup and implementation simple.


You Can Help Bring Quests to Deserving Students and Teachers Across the Country

What Makes A "DESERVING SCHOOL"?

Our Costs

The majority of our costs (about 55%) go directly to paying Teachers - the Quest Authors who pour their experience into the classroom into every Challenge.  Who insisted that we have 3 levels of difficulty for ALL of them.  Who know what it's like for teachers, where "Time is a gift", so Questily has to be simple for teachers to use and add a LOT of value.  The full cost breakdown estimates are shown in this pie chart below.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute a few bucks right now, HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

  • Get the word out and MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT QUESTILY, to help us help teachers MAKE LEARNING A TEAM SPORT.
  • The Indiegogo share tools are a great way to spread the word (as well as Facebook, email, etc).  


It's been A Team Effort: In particular, I was helped by exceptional teachers, who developed Questily's pedagogy and authored literally hundreds of Challenges (each with 3 levels of difficulty!), with special recognition to Natalie McNeill, Meredith Heathfield, Cathy Zyra, Jenn Noncek-Eastman, and Cynthia Smith.  I have an amazing development team helping make my vision a reality.   And I would have quit years ago without the encouragement and support of family and friends in Barrington, RI and here in Chicago, with an Advisory Board that any startup would envy.  Finally a shout-out to my friend and mentor, Professor Mohan Sawhney, who co-authored the case, and challenged me to go "all in".

story:
SHORT AND SIMPLE

When I saw this video on facebook, I commented there that this video should be aired as a commercial in every country before and after every countries evening news, during halftime at sports events etc etc.

This project aims to do just that. From the project title you can deduce that it is going to be a long flight of stairs. An old saying goes `Want a better world, start with bettering yourself`.

While watching the video, there where memories popping up, where I could identify myself with the bum, and memories where I could identify myself with the shop owner.

I believe this video inspires to reasonable, self-critical behaviour.

That's why I think it should not be limited to the internet, but should be shown relentlessly, like a commercial.

The funds coming in on this project, will be used only for that. Buying commercial airtime to show this video. No alterior commercial motive. The video, as is.

I set this project for flexible funding, and a low amount. That is, after the amount gets reached the project is still open to receive funds. All funds received will be spent on commercial airtime for this film only.

greetings,

Richard Kloostra

story:
Who are we?

The Elemental Dragons are a high school robotics team from Statesville, NC. We are an Iredell County 4-H club, and compete in the FIRST Robotics Competition. Through many local and regional events, our club reaches thousands of people, teaching the importance of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). We have had over 50 unique club members since the club's creation in 2010. Every year we build a unique robot to compete with, teaching local children the importance of engineering in their daily lives.


What do we need?

We need your help in funding our club for the 2016 Robotics Season. Below is an approximate budget for the season.


What does this impact?

We live in a world today where science and technology are the forefront of almost every industry. To teach the teens of today the skills they need for the future is a phenomenal task. We have been a club for over 5 years, and we have competed in a competition for every year since then. Through dedication and hard work, we have taught hundreds of people how STEM impacts their daily lives.


What are the risks and challenges?

Every year, we must build a robot to compete in a competition throughout North Carolina. Even if the team has bumps along the road, it gives them a view into the real-world aspect of engineering. We are currently at-risk for not attending the district competition, which is why we need your help for funding. 


How else can I help?

Tell everyone you know to help us out! Share this campaign on your social media platforms! Together, we can grow the world of science and technology. Email me@myork.net if you are interested in becoming an annual sponsor, which includes many more benefits.

story:
Short Summary

We are FRC Team 4534, the Wired Wizards. FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) is a worldwide competition where high school students have 6 weeks to design, build, and program a fully-functioning, 120lb, remote controllable robot to compete against other robots in a game of intelligence, cunning, and strategy. We are based in Wilmington, North Carolina, and we accept any high school student from any school, including home-school.

For more information about FIRST, check out http://usfirst.org.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to go to competition this year. We have a fundraising goal of $5,000 this year to go to our district competitions and regional championship. NC FIRST Robotics has recently moved to a new district model, allowing us to compete at two competitions (over the previous years single competition model) for a lower cost. The $5,000 that we raise through IndieGoGo will pay for our registration at the district level.  This registration is due on November 23rd, 2015. Any donation you make allows you the opportunity to select Perks, which are small tokens of our appreciation for helping our cause. To receive a perk, you must select it at checkout. If you select a perk, be sure to provide a valid email address so we can contact you if there are any problems, or if we need a business logo from you, for example.

Stretch Goals

In the event we meet our bare-minimum $5,000 goal, we still have much further to go. We have stretch goals listed here that will make competing easier for our team.

$8,500 - Robot Costs
If we raise an additional $3,500, we can afford to pay for all the parts for our bot and build a practice bot to work on after bag-n-tag date!

$10,000 - Marketing and Competition Resources
Marketing in a First Robotics Competition is more than fliers and buttons. Students must market themselves to other teams in order to attract and build alliances. This additional budget will support materials to increase team awareness in the community as well as giving us a bigger presence in competition.

$20,000 - Travel Costs
As you might imagine, travelling for 2-3 days with 30 high school kids plus chaperons and equipment can get expensive quick.  This year we have not one, but two guaranteed competitions that will demand travel. This stretch goal will fund our two trips and ensure we can keep all students fed and well rested while on the road!

The Impact

By contributing to our campaign, you will be contributing to the education of all of our team members.

  • FRC is a global educational opportunity for our team members that encourages engineering, applied math, programming, entrepreneurship, and leadership to prepare us for jobs in the future workforce.
  • US FIRST offers many scholarships and internship opportunities for students participating in FRC and also looks great on our college transcripts.
  • We need your support, and if you help us, you will truly be contributing to a great educational cause.

Risks

Your donations will ensure that our team of over 30 high school students have the resources necessary to participate in the 2016 competitive season of the US First Robotics Competition. Indiegogo is not our only source of fundraising.  Team 4534 is backed by a nonprofit organization, Port City Robotics, that continually seeks community funding resources and support.  100% of donations made to the core asking in this Indiegogo campaign will go to registration costs imposed by US First. Funds raised above and beyond the initial $5,000 will be earmarked towards their respective stretch goals. No staff of Port City Robotics or the Wired Wizards are paid through these proceeds. Should the campaign fail to reach its goal, the remaining funding will be ensured through the generosity of our community.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Check out our website for updates about our team at http://www.wiredwizards.org.
  • Spread the word about our campaign to your family, friends, and co-workers.
  • Check out our Facebook page.
  • Re-post our campaign link to your Facebook page and Tweet about us, please!
  • Email us your email address so you can stay updated with the team through our community email list: contact@wiredwizards.org

Thank you from all the members of FRC Team 4534, the Wired Wizards!

Spread the word about our campaign to your family, friends, and co-workers.
Check out our Facebook page.

Re-post our campaign link to your Facebook page and Tweet about us, please! 
Email us your email address so you can stay updated with the team through our community email list: contact@wiredwizards.org
Thank you from all the members of FRC Team 4534, the Wired Wizards!

story:
Akwaaba! Hello friends, family and international community! My name is Benjamin Cohn, and I have been living and studying in Ghana for the last 9 months on a Fulbright-mtvU Fellowship.  While researching music and the effects that it has on the people, their culture and politics, I have become even more convinced of the necessity of music education for the youth. Fostering self-expression and creativity is an essential part of personal and community development and since music was removed from the core curriculum in public schools, the work of places like the Bizung School of Music and Dance is more important than ever.

My research has produced countless interviews, essays and articles reinforcing music’s power to enact positive change in communities big and small. Education is an essential component of using that power to its full extent. I am partnering with Mohammed Alidu, Founder and Creative Director of the BizungSchool of Music &Dance, to help expand their operation and provide more children in Northern Ghana with access to quality music education. This project will provide a more tangible and immediate contribution to the Ghanaian community, and the people who have taught me so much.

Upon its founding in 2010, Alidu, as he's known to the students, named it after the talking drum chiefs, the "Bizung", who have lived in the area for more than 1,000 years. Today, the school employs 9 teachers with about 200 kids served, providing a nursery for the young, that runs most of the day, and the formal after-school classes for students aged 8+. These classes teach Ghanaian youth traditional and modern instruments and musical skills such as the xylophone, piano, drum and guitar; component notation; dance; and others.  Bizung has done an amazing job serving the immediate community in Tamale, but there are areas of need that we can help both locally and regionally. First, they need more guitars to replace old and broken ones as well as to serve more students.  Furthermore, Alidu has big plans for the school and the first step towards expansion is a van. The entire region lacks music education and a new van will allow Bizung to bring more students to the school, and bring musicians and teachers to more remote, outlying areas. It will help keep operations sustainable by providing new sources of income (rentals) and creating jobs in the community (drivers).

The three main goals for this expansion campaign:

1. 10 New guitars (5 acoustic, 3 bass, 2 electric) costing roughly $1600 (6,400 GHS)

2. New van to help with transportation needs costing roughly $3,500 (12,000 GHS)

3. Money for maintenance of items 1 and 2 costing roughly $1000 (4,000 GHS)

It is my aim to fund all three of these goals over the next 6 weeks but even accomplishing just one will be a major help to Bizung. Any donation, (no matter how big!) is appreciated and if you cannot support financially, please spread word about the campaign! 

To learn more about the school:

https://www.facebook.com/bizungschooltamale

http://playingforchange.org/programs/detail/bizung_school_of_music_and_dance

To read about my visits to Bizung with more videos and photos:

http://ghanabenja.blogspot.com/2015/08/the-powe...
